question_text: Write IUPAC names of the following compounds and classify them into primary, secondary and tertiary amines. (i) (CH₃)₂CHNH₂, (ii) CH₃(CH₂)₂NH₂, (iii) CH₃NHCH(CH₃)₂, (iv) (CH₃)₃CNH₂, (v) C₆H₅NHCH₃, (vi) (CH₃CH₂)₂NCH₃, (vii) m-BrC₆H₄NH₂.
correct_answer: For example: (i) 2-Aminopropane (primary amine); (ii) Butan-1-amine (primary amine); (iii) N-Methylpropan-2-amine (secondary amine); (iv) 2-Aminobutane, actually tert-butylamine (primary amine); (v) N-Methylaniline (secondary amine); (vi) N-Methyldiethylamine (tertiary amine); (vii) meta-Bromoaniline (primary amine).
explanation: Each compound is named by applying IUPAC rules for amines. Primary amines have –NH₂ attached to one carbon, secondary ones have one hydrogen replaced by an alkyl/aryl group on nitrogen, and tertiary amines have no N–H bonds. For instance, (i) has two methyl groups attached to a CH center with –NH₂ making it 2-aminopropane, and (v) with a phenyl substituent and a methyl group gives N-methylaniline.

question_text: Give one chemical test to distinguish between the following pairs of compounds: (i) methylamine and dimethylamine, (ii) secondary and tertiary amines, (iii) ethylamine and aniline, (iv) aniline and benzylamine, (v) aniline and N-methylaniline.
correct_answer: A common test is the Hinsberg reaction. In this test, primary amines (and to some extent benzylamines) react with benzenesulphonyl chloride to form sulphonamides that are soluble in alkali, while tertiary amines do not react. Also, the carbylamine reaction is positive only for primary amines. Thus, using a combination of the Hinsberg test and the carbylamine reaction one can distinguish between these pairs.
explanation: The Hinsberg test differentiates amines based on their reactivity with benzenesulphonyl chloride. Primary amines form sulphonamides soluble in alkali, secondary give derivatives insoluble in alkali, and tertiary amines do not react. The carbylamine reaction (using CHCl₃ and alcoholic KOH) gives isocyanides only for primary amines. These tests together can distinguish between methylamine vs dimethylamine and others.

question_text:
Account for the following:
(i) pK₍b₎ of aniline is more than that of methylamine.
(ii) Ethylamine is soluble in water whereas aniline is not.
(iii) Methylamine in water reacts with ferric chloride to precipitate hydrated ferric oxide.
(iv) Although the amino group is ortho- and para-directing in aromatic electrophilic substitution reactions, aniline on nitration gives a substantial amount of meta-nitroaniline.
(v) Aniline does not undergo Friedel-Crafts reaction.
(vi) Diazonium salts of aromatic amines are more stable than those of aliphatic amines.
(vii) Gabriel phthalimide synthesis is preferred for synthesising primary amines.
correct_answer: Answers include: (i) In aniline, the lone pair is delocalized into the aromatic ring and is less available for protonation, resulting in a higher pK₍b₎ than methylamine. (ii) Ethylamine readily forms hydrogen bonds with water due to its small hydrophobic part, whereas the larger aromatic ring in aniline reduces water solubility. (iii) Methylamine forms a complex with ferric chloride causing precipitation of hydrated ferric oxide. (iv) Under nitration conditions, protonation of the amino group occurs, forming anilinium ion which is meta-directing. (v) Aniline forms strong complexes with Lewis acids (e.g., AlCl₃), inhibiting Friedel-Crafts reactions. (vi) Aromatic diazonium salts benefit from resonance stabilization, making them more stable than aliphatic diazonium salts. (vii) Gabriel synthesis avoids over-alkylation and is effective for primary amines because aryl halides are unreactive toward the phthalimide anion.
explanation: Each part requires application of concepts such as resonance, hydrogen bonding, solvation, and reagent reactivity. The reduced basicity of aniline is due to lone pair delocalization, while solubility differences and reactivity with ferric chloride are related to structural effects. Electrophilic substitution behavior is explained by protonation and directing effects, and the stability of diazonium salts is a consequence of resonance. Finally, the limitations of alkylation are overcome by Gabriel synthesis.

question_text:

(vi) In increasing order of solubility in water: C₆H₅NH₂, (C₂H₅)₂NH, C₂H₅NH₂.
correct_answer: Based on provided data and discussion: (i) C₆H₅NH₂ < NH₃ < C₆H₅CH₂NH₂ < C₂H₅NH₂; (ii) C₆H₅NH₂ < C₂H₅NH₂ < (C₂H₅)₃N < (C₂H₅)₂NH; (iii) (a) Aniline < p-nitroaniline < p-toluidine, (b) C₆H₅NH₂ < C₆H₅NHCH₃ < C₆H₅CH₂NH₂; (iv) C₂H₅NH₂ > (C₂H₅)₂NH > (C₂H₅)₃N > NH₃; (v) C₂H₅OH < (CH₃)₂NH < C₂H₅NH₂; (vi) C₆H₅NH₂ < (C₂H₅)₂NH < C₂H₅NH₂.
explanation: These arrangements involve comparing basicity, boiling points and solubility based on factors such as inductive effect, hydrogen bonding and steric hindrance. For example, in the aqueous phase, primary amines tend to be more basic due to better solvation compared to tertiary amines, while in the gas phase the inductive effect dominates.

question_text:
How will you convert:
(i) Ethanoic acid into methanamine,
(ii) Hexanenitrile into 1-aminopentane,
(iii) Methanol into ethanoic acid,
(iv) Ethanamine into methanamine,
(v) Ethanoic acid into propanoic acid,
(vi) Methanamine into ethanamine,
(vii) Nitromethane into dimethylamine,
(viii) Propanoic acid into ethanoic acid?
correct_answer: A plausible answer: (i) Convert ethanoic acid to acetamide (using ammonia) and perform a Hofmann bromamide degradation to yield methanamine; (ii) Convert hexanenitrile to hexanamide by reduction followed by the Hofmann reaction to lose one carbon, yielding 1-aminopentane; (iii) Oxidize methanol (via formaldehyde and formic acid intermediates) and perform a chain extension or using controlled oxidation to form ethanoic acid; (iv) Convert ethanamine to ethanamide then subject it to Hofmann degradation to give methanamine; (v) Employ a chain homologation reaction (such as via malonic ester synthesis) to extend ethanoic acid to propanoic acid; (vi) Convert methanamine into its nitrile (by reaction with a one-carbon electrophile) and then reduce to ethanamine; (vii) Condensation and reduction of nitromethane (possibly forming intermediates that on further methylation yield dimethylamine); (viii) Use a decarboxylation method to shorten propanoic acid to ethanoic acid.
explanation: Each conversion involves either a chain extension or chain shortening reaction. Reactions such as the Hofmann bromamide degradation allow the transformation of amides to amines with one carbon less. Reduction of nitriles, oxidation of alcohols, and homologation reactions are commonly used in amine synthesis. The answer outlines a sequence of reactions based on known methods discussed in the chapter.
topic: Conversion Reactions and Preparation of Amines

question_text: Describe a method for the identification of primary, secondary and tertiary amines. Also write chemical equations of the reactions involved.
correct_answer: The Hinsberg test is commonly used. In this test, the amine is reacted with benzenesulphonyl chloride in the presence of an alkaline medium. Primary amines form N-alkylbenzenesulphonamides soluble in alkali, secondary amines form sulphonamides that are insoluble, and tertiary amines do not react. The general equations are: R–NH₂ + C₆H₅SO₂Cl → C₆H₅SO₂–NHR + HCl (primary amine), and similarly for secondary amines. Tertiary amines show no reaction.
explanation: The Hinsberg test exploits the differences in nucleophilicity and steric hindrance of the amine nitrogen. The solubility of the resulting sulphonamide in alkali further distinguishes primary and secondary amines. This method reliably distinguishes between the three classes based on their different reactivity with benzenesulphonyl chloride.

question_text:
Write short notes on the following:
(i) Carbylamine reaction
(ii) Diazotisation
(iii) Hofmann's bromamide reaction
(iv) Coupling reaction
(v) Ammonolysis
(vi) Acetylation
(vii) Gabriel phthalimide synthesis.
correct_answer: Briefly: (i) Carbylamine reaction is the conversion of a primary amine with CHCl₃ and alcoholic KOH to form an isocyanide (with a foul odor); (ii) Diazotisation is the conversion of a primary aromatic amine to a diazonium salt using NaNO₂ and acid at 0–5°C; (iii) Hofmann's bromamide reaction converts an amide to an amine with one less carbon using Br₂ and NaOH; (iv) Coupling reaction involves the reaction of diazonium salts with activated aromatic compounds (like phenol or aniline) to form azo dyes; (v) Ammonolysis is the nucleophilic substitution of a halide by ammonia to form an amine; (vi) Acetylation of an amine (using acetic anhydride or acetyl chloride) protects the NH₂ group; (vii) Gabriel phthalimide synthesis prepares primary amines by alkylation of phthalimide followed by hydrolysis.
explanation: These short notes summarize important reactions and methods for amine synthesis and modification. Each reaction has a specific role: for instance, carbylamine reaction is used as a test for primary amines, while diazotisation is crucial for further substitution reactions on aromatic rings.

question_text:
Accomplish the following conversions:
(i) Nitrobenzene to benzoic acid
(ii) Benzene to m-bromophenol
(iii) Benzoic acid to aniline
(iv) Aniline to 2,4,6-tribromofluorobenzene
(v) Benzyl chloride to 2-phenylethanamine
(vi) Chlorobenzene to p-chloroaniline
(vii) Aniline to p-bromoaniline
(viii) Benzamide to toluene
(ix) Aniline to benzyl alcohol.
correct_answer: A sample answer: (i) Nitrobenzene can be reduced to aniline and then oxidized under controlled conditions to benzoic acid; (ii) Benzene can undergo electrophilic substitution (nitration followed by substitution) to yield m-bromophenol; (iii) Benzoic acid can be converted to benzoyl chloride and then subjected to amination to form aniline; (iv) Aniline is brominated (under controlled conditions) to yield 2,4,6-tribromofluorobenzene; (v) Benzyl chloride undergoes ammonolysis to give benzylamine which can then be extended to 2-phenylethanamine by reaction with CH₃Cl; (vi) Chlorobenzene can be converted to p-chloroaniline via nucleophilic aromatic substitution (often after catalyst activation); (vii) Aniline can be acetylated, brominated, and then hydrolyzed to yield p-bromoaniline; (viii) Benzamide can be reduced (via a dehydration route) to yield toluene; (ix) Aniline can be converted to benzyl alcohol through diazotisation followed by replacement with hydroxyl.
explanation: These transformations require multi-step sequences involving reduction, oxidation, nucleophilic substitution, and electrophilic aromatic substitution. Each conversion uses standard organic transformations discussed in the chapter, and a clear understanding of reaction conditions is required.

(ii) C₆H₅N₂Cl⁻ → (CuCN) → A → (H₂O/H⁺) → B → (NH₃, Δ) → C

correct_answer: A model answer would assign structures as follows: For (i), A is CH₃CH₂CN (ethyl cyanide), B is the corresponding imidate or partially hydrolyzed intermediate, and C is ethylamine after base treatment with Br₂; (ii) starting from benzenediazonium chloride, A is the cyanobenzene (via Sandmeyer reaction), B is the hydrolyzed product (benzoic acid or phenol depending on conditions), and C is the amine after treatment with ammonia; (iii) A is propionitrile from ethyl bromide, B is an intermediate reduced by LiAlH₄ to propylamine, and C is a product of a diazotisation reaction; (iv–vi) follow similar patterns where reduction of nitrobenzene forms aniline derivatives, which after diazotisation and subsequent reactions yield substituted aromatic compounds. question_text: An aromatic compound ‘A’ on treatment with aqueous ammonia and heating forms compound ‘B’ which on heating with Br₂ and KOH forms a compound ‘C’ of molecular formula C₆H₇N. Write the structures and IUPAC names of compounds A, B and C.
correct_answer: A plausible answer is: A is benzoyl chloride (C₆H₅COCl), which on treatment with aqueous ammonia yields benzamide (C₆H₅CONH₂) as compound B; subsequent Hofmann bromamide degradation (using Br₂ and KOH) converts benzamide into aniline (C₆H₅NH₂), which has the molecular formula C₆H₇N, as compound C.
explanation: Benzoyl chloride reacts with ammonia to form benzamide. In the Hofmann degradation, an amide loses a carbon (as carbon dioxide equivalent) and is converted to the corresponding amine. Here, benzamide (a seven-carbon compound) yields aniline (a six-carbon aromatic amine), consistent with the given formula.

question_text: Why cannot aromatic primary amines be prepared by Gabriel phthalimide synthesis?
correct_answer: Aromatic primary amines cannot be prepared by Gabriel phthalimide synthesis because aryl halides (the starting materials for introducing the aromatic moiety) do not undergo nucleophilic substitution with the phthalimide anion due to their low reactivity and the stabilization provided by the aromatic ring.
explanation: The Gabriel synthesis is effective for aliphatic amines because aliphatic halides are sufficiently reactive toward nucleophilic attack by the phthalimide ion. In the case of aryl halides, the partial double bond character of the carbon–halogen bond and resonance stabilization inhibit the substitution reaction.

question_text: Write the reactions of (i) aromatic and (ii) aliphatic primary amines with nitrous acid.
correct_answer: (i) Aromatic primary amines: C₆H₅NH₂ + NaNO₂ + 2HCl (0–5°C) → C₆H₅N₂⁺Cl⁻ + NaCl + 2H₂O. (ii) Aliphatic primary amines: R–NH₂ + HNO₂ → unstable aliphatic diazonium salt which decomposes to ROH (alcohol) + N₂ + HCl.
explanation: Aromatic primary amines form stable diazonium salts at low temperatures which can be isolated and further reacted, while aliphatic diazonium salts are unstable and decompose, typically forming alcohols after hydrolysis.

question_text:
Give plausible explanations for each of the following:
(i) Why are amines less acidic than alcohols of comparable molecular masses?
(ii) Why do primary amines have higher boiling points than tertiary amines?
(iii) Why are aliphatic amines stronger bases than aromatic amines?
correct_answer: (i) Amines are less acidic than alcohols because the N–H bond is less polarized than the O–H bond due to the lower electronegativity of nitrogen compared to oxygen. (ii) Primary amines have higher boiling points because they can form more intermolecular hydrogen bonds (with two available N–H groups) than tertiary amines, which lack N–H bonds. (iii) Aliphatic amines are stronger bases than aromatic amines because in aromatic amines the lone pair on nitrogen is delocalized into the aromatic ring, making it less available for protonation.
explanation: The acidity and boiling point differences arise from the nature of the X–H bond (O–H vs. N–H) and the extent of intermolecular hydrogen bonding. In aromatic amines, resonance stabilization reduces the availability of the lone pair, thus decreasing basicity compared to aliphatic amines.
topic: Physical and Chemical Properties of Amines

question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the physical state and odor of lower aliphatic amines?
options: They are liquids with a fruity odor
They are gases with a fishy odor
They are solids with a pungent odor
They are liquids with no noticeable odor

question_text: Out of butan-1-ol and butan-1-amine, which is more soluble in water and why?
options: Butan-1-ol, because the oxygen atom of the hydroxyl group is more electronegative and forms stronger hydrogen bonds
Butan-1-amine, because nitrogen readily donates electrons
Both are equally soluble due to similar molar masses
Butan-1-amine, because it has a higher boiling point
correct_answer: Butan-1-ol, because the oxygen atom of the hydroxyl group is more electronegative and forms stronger hydrogen bonds
explanation: The solubility comparison stems from the fact that oxygen (electronegativity 3.5) forms stronger hydrogen bonds compared to nitrogen (electronegativity 3.0), making butan-1-ol more soluble in water.

question_text: Which type of amine does not engage in intermolecular hydrogen bonding?
correct_answer: Tertiary amine
explanation: Tertiary amines do not have a hydrogen atom available on the nitrogen for hydrogen bond formation, unlike primary or secondary amines.

question_text: Arrange the isomeric amines in order of decreasing boiling points based on their ability to form hydrogen bonds.
correct_answer: Primary > Secondary > Tertiary
explanation: Primary amines have two hydrogen atoms available for hydrogen bonding, secondary have one, and tertiary have none, leading to the observed order of boiling points.

question_text: What is the primary reason that aniline and other arylamines tend to become colored upon storage?
options: They absorb moisture from the atmosphere.
Their molecular structure changes due to temperature fluctuations.
They react with light to form colored complexes.
correct_answer: They undergo atmospheric oxidation.
explanation: Aromatic amines like aniline initially appear colourless but become colored on storage due to oxidation processes when exposed to the atmosphere.

question_text: Explain why lower aliphatic amines are more soluble in water compared to higher amines.
correct_answer: Lower aliphatic amines are more soluble in water because their smaller hydrophobic alkyl group size allows effective hydrogen bonding with water. As the alkyl chain increases, the hydrophobic character increases, reducing solubility.
explanation: The solubility of amines in water is primarily due to the ability to form hydrogen bonds. With an increase in the size of the alkyl portion, the hydrophobic effect overcomes the hydrogen bonding capability, leading to decreased solubility.

question_text: Describe how the molecular size of an amine influences its solubility in water.
correct_answer: As the molecular size of an amine increases, especially the length of the hydrophobic alkyl chain, its solubility in water decreases because the larger nonpolar part interferes with hydrogen bonding with water.
explanation: The balance between the polar, hydrogen bonding part and the nonpolar alkyl chain is critical. A larger hydrophobic segment decreases overall solubility in aqueous environments.

question_text: How does intermolecular hydrogen bonding differ between primary and secondary amines?
correct_answer: Primary amines, having two hydrogen atoms on the nitrogen, can form more hydrogen bonds than secondary amines, which have only one hydrogen available for donation. This results in stronger intermolecular associations in primary amines.
explanation: The number of N—H bonds available for hydrogen bonding directly influences the strength of intermolecular attractions. Primary amines can form two hydrogen bonds per molecule compared to only one in secondary amines.

question_text: Discuss the role of electronegativity of nitrogen and oxygen in determining the water solubility of amines and alcohols.
correct_answer: Oxygen has a higher electronegativity (3.5) compared to nitrogen (3.0), allowing alcohols to form stronger hydrogen bonds with water than amines. This difference accounts for the greater solubility of alcohols in water despite similar molar masses.
explanation: The ability of a molecule to participate in hydrogen bonding is influenced by the electronegativity of the atoms involved. Since oxygen attracts electrons more strongly than nitrogen, alcohols tend to interact more effectively with water molecules.

question_text: Analyze the relationship between intermolecular hydrogen bonding and boiling points for amines, alcohols, and alkanes of similar molar masses using the data provided in Table 9.2.
correct_answer: The data in Table 9.2 show that n-C4H9OH has the highest boiling point, followed by n-C4H9NH2, then (C2H5)2NH, and finally the alkane, iso-pentane. This trend is explained by the strength and number of possible intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Alcohols, with oxygen, form stronger hydrogen bonds than amines, and within amines, primary types can form more hydrogen bonds than secondary or tertiary types. Alkanes, lacking any polar groups for hydrogen bonding, rely solely on weak dispersion forces.
explanation: By comparing the boiling points, it is clear that hydrogen bonding greatly influences boiling points. The higher boiling point for n-C4H9OH is due to strong hydrogen bonding with the hydroxyl group. In amines, the availability of N—H bonds determines the extent of hydrogen bonding, with primary > secondary > tertiary. Alkanes, with only London dispersion forces, have the lowest boiling point.

question_text: Evaluate how the substitution of hydrogen atoms in amines influences their boiling points. In your answer, compare primary, secondary, and tertiary amines.
correct_answer: Substituting hydrogen atoms in amines reduces the number of hydrogen bond donors available for intermolecular bonding. Primary amines, with two N—H bonds, exhibit the highest boiling points due to stronger and more extensive hydrogen bonding. Secondary amines have only one N—H bond, leading to moderately lower boiling points, while tertiary amines lack any N—H bonds and rely on weaker dipole interactions, resulting in the lowest boiling points among isomeric amines.
explanation: The boiling point of a compound is greatly influenced by the strength and number of intermolecular forces present. In amines, fewer hydrogen atoms on the nitrogen mean fewer opportunities for hydrogen bonding, which directly translates to lower boiling points.

question_text: Design an experiment to compare the solubility of butan-1-ol and butan-1-amine in water. Outline the key steps, controls, and expected observations based on their molecular structures.
correct_answer: An experimental design would involve preparing solutions of equal molar concentrations of butan-1-ol and butan-1-amine in distilled water. Steps include: measuring equal volumes of water, adding fixed amounts of each compound separately, stirring and equilibrating, and then visually observing the extent of mixing or using spectrophotometric methods to determine concentration in the aqueous phase. Controls should include water alone and a known soluble compound. Based on molecular structure, it is expected that butan-1-ol will show higher solubility due to stronger hydrogen bonding from the hydroxyl group compared to the amine group in butan-1-amine.
explanation: The experiment must systematically compare the solubility by controlling concentration, temperature, and stirring time. Molecular structure analysis indicates that the higher electronegativity of oxygen in butan-1-ol gives it an advantage in forming hydrogen bonds with water compared to butan-1-amine, leading to higher solubility.

question_text: Tertiary amines do not engage in intermolecular hydrogen bonding due to the absence of hydrogen atoms on the nitrogen. True or False?
correct_answer: True
explanation: Tertiary amines lack N—H bonds, which are essential for intermolecular hydrogen bonding, making the statement true.

explanation: The difference in boiling points between n-C4H9NH2 (a primary amine) and (C2H5)2NH (a secondary amine) is 350.8 K - 329.3 K = 21.5 K. This difference can be attributed to the additional hydrogen bonding capability of the primary amine compared to the secondary amine.

question_text: An unknown compound with a molar mass similar to n-C4H9NH2 has a boiling point of 360 K. Based on Table 9.2 data, deduce its likely classification among amines (primary, secondary, or tertiary) and justify your reasoning.
correct_answer: The unknown compound is most likely a primary amine.

explanation: According to Table 9.2, n-C4H9NH2 boils at 350.8 K and (C2H5)2NH at 329.3 K, making the difference 350.8 K - 329.3 K = 21.5 K. This does not match the expected decrease of 19 K.

question_text: The reaction in which the diazonium group is replaced by halide or cyanide ions in the presence of Cu(I) is known as:
correct_answer: Sandmeyer reaction

question_text: What reaction occurs when the temperature of a benzenediazonium salt solution is allowed to rise to 283 K?

explanation: When the temperature of a diazonium salt solution is raised to 283 K, it undergoes hydrolysis resulting in the formation of phenol, along with the release of N₂ and HCl.

question_text: Which of the following is NOT used as a reducing agent to replace the diazonium group with a hydrogen atom?
correct_answer: Sodium nitrite
explanation: Hypophosphorous acid and ethanol are mild reducing agents used to convert diazonium salts to arenes by replacing the diazonium group with hydrogen. Sodium nitrite, however, is used in reactions that introduce a -NO₂ group, not as a reducing agent.

question_text: What is the role of Cu(I) ions in the Sandmeyer reaction involving diazonium salts?
options: They act as a catalyst facilitating nucleophilic substitution.
They precipitate as insoluble salts removing impurities.
They serve as a reducing agent converting the diazonium group to hydrogen.
correct_answer: They act as a catalyst facilitating nucleophilic substitution.
explanation: Cu(I) ions are essential in the Sandmeyer reaction because they catalyze the substitution of the diazonium group with nucleophiles like Cl⁻, Br⁻, or CN⁻, thereby allowing the reaction to proceed with the liberation of nitrogen.

question_text: Describe the physical properties of benzenediazonium chloride and benzenediazonium fluoroborate.
correct_answer: Benzenediazonium chloride is a colourless crystalline solid that is readily soluble in water and is stable in cold conditions, though it reacts with water when warmed and decomposes easily in the dry state. In contrast, benzenediazonium fluoroborate is water insoluble and remains stable at room temperature.
explanation: This answer details the contrasting solubility and thermal stability of the two diazonium salts, as described in the text.

question_text: Explain the differences between the Sandmeyer and Gattermann reactions in terms of reagents, conditions, and yields.
correct_answer: The Sandmeyer reaction employs Cu(I) salts with corresponding halogen acids to replace the diazonium group with nucleophiles such as Cl⁻, Br⁻, and CN⁻ and generally gives better yields. The Gattermann reaction, on the other hand, uses copper powder along with the halogen acid and introduces the halogen into the benzene ring but typically results in lower yields compared to the Sandmeyer reaction.
explanation: The answer contrasts the two methods by highlighting the catalysts used (Cu(I) salts versus copper powder) and noting the yield differences, as well as the overall effectiveness of each method.

question_text: Outline the mechanism of the coupling reaction between benzenediazonium chloride and phenol to form p-hydroxyazobenzene.
correct_answer: In the coupling reaction, benzenediazonium chloride reacts with phenol in a basic medium (pH 9-10), where the phenol provides an electron-rich aromatic ring. The nucleophilic attack occurs at the para position relative to the hydroxyl group, resulting in the formation of the azo linkage (–N=N–), yielding p-hydroxyazobenzene.
explanation: This explanation describes the electrophilic aromatic substitution mechanism, specifically how the diazonium ion couples with the activated aromatic ring of phenol to form an azo dye.

question_text: What happens when arenediazonium chloride is treated with hypophosphorous acid? Provide the reaction outcome and the oxidation product formed.
correct_answer: When arenediazonium chloride is treated with hypophosphorous acid, it is reduced to the corresponding arene. In this process, the diazonium group is replaced by a hydrogen atom, and hypophosphorous acid is oxidized to phosphorous acid (H₃PO₃), with nitrogen gas being liberated.
explanation: The answer identifies the reducing action of H₃PO₂ on the diazonium salt, leading to the formation of an arene and phosphorous acid, which aligns with the chemical reaction described in the text.

question_text: Discuss in detail the two broad categories of reactions of diazonium salts. Compare the mechanisms of reactions involving displacement of nitrogen and those involving retention of the diazo group, and provide examples of each type as given in the text.
correct_answer: The reactions of diazonium salts are divided into two categories. In reactions involving displacement of nitrogen, the diazonium group acts as a good leaving group and is substituted by nucleophiles such as halides (Cl⁻, Br⁻, I⁻), cyanide, hydroxyl, or even hydrogen, with the liberated nitrogen being released as a gas. Examples include the Sandmeyer reaction (replacement by Cl⁻, Br⁻, CN⁻), the reaction with KI to form iodobenzene, and reductions by hypophosphorous acid or ethanol. In contrast, reactions retaining the diazo group involve coupling reactions where the diazonium ion reacts with aromatic compounds like phenol or aniline to form azo dyes, thereby retaining the –N=N– linkage in the product. This category relies on electrophilic aromatic substitution mechanisms, resulting in colored compounds used in dye industries.
explanation: This comprehensive answer discusses both types of reactions by detailing the replacement of nitrogen with various nucleophiles versus the formation of azo bonds in coupling reactions, illustrating the mechanistic differences between the two categories.

question_text: Compare and contrast the reactions of arenediazonium salts with halide ions (such as Cl⁻, Br⁻, and I⁻) focusing on the role of catalysts, reaction conditions, and the differences in reaction yields between the Sandmeyer and Gattermann reactions.
correct_answer: Arenediazonium salts react with halide ions through two main processes. The Sandmeyer reaction uses Cu(I) salts along with the suitable halogen acid to introduce Cl⁻, Br⁻, or CN⁻ into the aromatic ring, generally resulting in higher yields and more controlled reaction conditions. In contrast, the Gattermann reaction employs copper powder with the halogen acid, which, although achieved under similar conditions, typically gives lower yields due to less efficient activation of the diazonium compound. The reaction conditions such as temperature and the nature of the copper species influence the rate and yield of the substitution reaction. Iodide ion introduction is distinct in that direct introduction is difficult, so potassium iodide is used separately without the need for copper catalysts.
explanation: The answer analyzes the two reaction types by highlighting the roles of catalysts (Cu(I) salt vs. copper powder), the reaction conditions, and yield differences, providing a clear comparison as detailed in the text.

question_text: Elaborate on the significance of diazonium coupling reactions in dye production. In your answer, discuss how reaction conditions such as pH affect the coupling of benzenediazonium chloride with phenol and aniline and the properties of the resulting dyes.
correct_answer: Diazonium coupling reactions are pivotal in the synthesis of azo dyes, which are extensively used in the textile and printing industries. In these reactions, benzenediazonium chloride couples with phenol in a basic medium (pH 9-10) to produce p-hydroxyazobenzene, which is generally orange, while its coupling with aniline in an acidic medium (pH 4-5) leads to the formation of p-aminoazobenzene, a yellow dye. The pH of the medium greatly influences the reactivity of the aromatic coupling partner, with the ionization state of phenol and aniline affecting the position and rate of electrophilic substitution. As a result, careful control of reaction conditions ensures the formation of dyes with desired color intensities and stabilities.
explanation: This answer describes the mechanistic importance of controlled pH in coupling reactions, explaining how these conditions impact the electronic characteristics of the aromatic compounds and, consequently, the properties of the dyes formed.

question_text: Benzenediazonium chloride decomposes easily in the presence of water even at cold temperatures.
correct_answer: False
explanation: Benzenediazonium chloride is stable in cold water but reacts with water when warmed; it does not decompose easily in cold conditions.

question_text: The Gattermann reaction uses copper powder and corresponding halogen acid to introduce chlorine or bromine into the benzene ring via the diazonium salt.
correct_answer: True
explanation: According to the text, the Gattermann reaction involves treating the diazonium salt solution with the corresponding halogen acid and copper powder, leading to the substitution reaction that introduces the halogen into the benzene ring.

question_text: In the Sandmeyer reaction, benzenediazonium chloride reacts to form chlorobenzene with the liberation of nitrogen gas. If you start with 0.5 mol of benzenediazonium chloride, calculate the mass of N₂ gas produced. (Molar mass of N₂ = 28 g/mol)
correct_answer: 14 g of N₂ gas
explanation: The reaction ArN₂⁺Cl⁻ → ArCl + N₂ indicates that 1 mole of diazonium salt produces 1 mole of N₂. Therefore, 0.5 mol of diazonium salt produces 0.5 mol of N₂. Multiplying the moles by the molar mass of N₂ gives: 0.5 mol × 28 g/mol = 14 g.

question_text: During a hydrolysis reaction, 0.2 mol of diazonium salt is completely converted to form phenol and nitrogen gas. Calculate the mass of N₂ gas released during the process. (Molar mass of N₂ = 28 g/mol)
correct_answer: 5.6 g of N₂ gas
explanation: In the hydrolysis reaction ArN₂⁺Cl⁻ + H₂O → ArOH + N₂ + HCl, 1 mole of diazonium salt generates 1 mole of N₂ gas. Therefore, 0.2 mol of diazonium salt yields 0.2 mol of N₂. Multiplying by the molar mass: 0.2 mol × 28 g/mol = 5.6 g of N₂.

question_text: When arenediazonium chloride reacts with fluoroboric acid followed by heating, the reaction produces aryl fluoride, BF₃, and N₂. If you start with 0.1 mol of arenediazonium salt, how many moles of BF₃ are expected to be produced?
correct_answer: 0.1 mol of BF₃
explanation: The reaction: ArN₂⁺Cl⁻ + HBF₄ → Ar–N₂⁺BF₄⁻ --(Δ)--> Ar–F + BF₃ + N₂, shows a 1:1 mole ratio between arenediazonium salt and BF₃. Thus, starting with 0.1 mol of the salt produces 0.1 mol of BF₃.

question_text: A Sandmeyer reaction gives an 85% yield while a Gattermann reaction gives a 60% yield for the conversion of 0.4 mol of diazonium salt to chlorobenzene. Calculate the number of moles of chlorobenzene produced in each case and determine the difference in moles between the two methods.
correct_answer: Sandmeyer: 0.34 mol; Gattermann: 0.24 mol; Difference: 0.10 mol
explanation: For the Sandmeyer reaction, 85% of 0.4 mol is 0.4 × 0.85 = 0.34 mol of product. For the Gattermann reaction, 60% of 0.4 mol is 0.4 × 0.60 = 0.24 mol. The difference in yield is 0.34 mol - 0.24 mol = 0.10 mol of chlorobenzene.

question_text: Which of the following reactions correctly represents the reaction of an amine with an acid to form its salt?
correct_answer: A: R–NH₂ + H–X ⇌ R–NH₃⁺X⁻
explanation: Amines being basic react with acids to form ammonium salts. The reaction R–NH₂ + H–X ⇌ R–NH₃⁺X⁻ is the correct representation of this process.

question_text: Which of the following effects is primarily responsible for making aliphatic amines stronger bases than ammonia?
options: A: Inductive withdrawal of electrons from nitrogen
B: Dispersion of positive charge via solvation alone
C: +I effect of alkyl groups increasing electron density on nitrogen
correct_answer: C: +I effect of alkyl groups increasing electron density on nitrogen
explanation: Aliphatic amines are more basic than ammonia because the alkyl groups donate electrons via the inductive (+I) effect, increasing electron density on the nitrogen atom and making its lone pair more available for protonation.

question_text: Which reaction is commonly used as a qualitative test to confirm the presence of a primary amine?
options: C: Carbylamine reaction with CHCl₃ and ethanolic KOH
D: Electrophilic nitration of aromatic amines
correct_answer: C: Carbylamine reaction with CHCl₃ and ethanolic KOH
explanation: The carbylamine reaction is specific to primary amines. In this reaction, a primary amine reacts with chloroform and ethanolic KOH to produce a foul-smelling isocyanide, thereby serving as a test for primary amines.

question_text: In electrophilic substitution reactions of aniline, the –NH₂ group directs substitution to which positions?
correct_answer: B: Ortho and para positions
explanation: The –NH₂ group in aniline donates electron density through resonance, creating regions of high electron density at the ortho and para positions. Therefore, electrophilic substitution predominantly occurs at these positions.

question_text: Regarding the reaction of benzenesulphonyl chloride (Hinsberg's reagent) with amines, which statement is correct?
options: A: Tertiary amines react to form sulphonamides.
B: Primary amines form N-alkylbenzenesulphonamides that are soluble in alkali.
C: Secondary amines form sulphonamides that are soluble in alkali.
D: Both primary and secondary amines form similar salts with benzenesulphonyl chloride.
correct_answer: B: Primary amines form N-alkylbenzenesulphonamides that are soluble in alkali.
explanation: Primary amines react with benzenesulphonyl chloride to give N-alkylbenzenesulphonamides with an N–H bond, which is acidic and makes them soluble in alkali. Tertiary amines do not react because they lack the hydrogen necessary for the reaction.

question_text: Explain why aniline exhibits a higher pKb value compared to aliphatic amines.
correct_answer: Aniline has a higher pKb value because the lone pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom in aniline is delocalized into the aromatic benzene ring via resonance. This delocalization makes the lone pair less available for protonation, thereby reducing its basicity compared to aliphatic amines where the lone pair is localized.
explanation: In aliphatic amines, the nitrogen’s lone pair is not involved in resonance and is more readily available to accept protons. Consequently, the basic strength is higher (lower pKb), whereas in aniline, resonance stabilization of the unshared electron pair diminishes its ability to act as a base, resulting in a higher pKb.

question_text: Describe the role of solvation in influencing the basicity of ammonium ions derived from primary, secondary, and tertiary amines in aqueous solution.
correct_answer: In aqueous solution, solvation stabilizes the ammonium ions formed from amines. Primary ammonium ions, having more hydrogen atoms available, can form more hydrogen bonds with water molecules, thereby achieving greater stabilization. Secondary ions form fewer hydrogen bonds, and tertiary ions, due to steric hindrance, form the least. This differential solvation influences the apparent basicity, often making primary amines stronger bases in water despite the inductive effects of alkyl groups.
explanation: The stability of the ammonium ion is not determined solely by the inductive effect; solvation plays a crucial role. More extensive hydrogen bonding in primary ammonium ions stabilizes the ion, thereby shifting the equilibrium towards ion formation, which results in a higher observed basicity in aqueous media.

question_text: Why is a base such as pyridine used in the acylation reaction of amines, and what role does this reaction play in organic synthesis?
correct_answer: Pyridine is used in the acylation reaction of amines because it acts as a base to neutralize the HCl formed during the reaction, thereby driving the equilibrium toward the product side. This acylation reaction converts an amine (-NH₂) into an amide (-NHCO-), which is less reactive. This transformation is valuable in synthesis as it serves both to protect the amine functionality during further reactions and to facilitate controlled downstream modifications, such as electrophilic substitutions on aromatic amines.
explanation: The removal of HCl by pyridine prevents the reverse reaction and ensures high yield of the acylated product. Moreover, converting an amine to an amide modulates its reactivity, making it useful for selective reactions in multi-step synthetic pathways.

question_text: Discuss the structure-basicity relationship of amines by comparing aliphatic amines with ammonia. In your answer, include the effects of inductive donation and solvation on their basicity.
correct_answer: Aliphatic amines are generally stronger bases than ammonia due to the +I (electron donating) effect of alkyl groups, which increases electron density on nitrogen, enhancing its ability to accept a proton. Additionally, when an aliphatic amine reacts with a proton, the resulting ammonium ion benefits from the dispersal of the positive charge by the alkyl groups. However, in aqueous solution, solvation plays a significant role. The smaller, less hindered primary ammonium ions are better solvated by water through hydrogen bonding than the bulkier secondary or tertiary ions. This solvation stabilizes the cation, making the protonation process more favorable. Therefore, while basicity in the gas phase often follows the order tertiary > secondary > primary due to the inductive effect, in aqueous solution the order is reversed (primary > secondary > tertiary) because of solvation effects.
explanation: This answer integrates both electronic (inductive effects) and physical (solvation) factors. The inductive effect increases the availability of the lone pair for protonation, while solvation stabilizes the ammonium ion. The net observed basicity is a balance between these factors and explains the different trends observed in various phases.

question_text: Explain how acetylation of aniline modifies its reactivity in electrophilic substitution reactions. In your answer, discuss the mechanism by which acetylation protects the amino group and leads to controlled nitration.
correct_answer: Acetylation of aniline converts the –NH₂ group into an –NHCOCH₃ group. This transformation occurs when aniline is treated with acetic anhydride (often in the presence of pyridine) to form acetanilide. In acetanilide, the lone pair on the nitrogen is partially delocalized towards the carbonyl group, reducing its electron-donating ability to the aromatic ring. As a result, the ring becomes less activated toward electrophilic attack and the directing influence of –NH₂, which is originally strongly ortho/para directing, is moderated. This modification prevents multiple substitutions during electrophilic reactions such as nitration, allowing for the selective formation of mono-substituted products, particularly the para derivative. After nitration, the acetyl protecting group can be removed by hydrolysis to yield the desired nitroaniline.
explanation: The acetylation step is crucial to temper the high reactivity of aniline. By protecting the amino group, the reaction avoids uncontrolled substitutions and oxidation. This strategy employs the concept of protecting groups in organic synthesis, ensuring selective reaction at desired positions on the aromatic ring.

question_text: Evaluate the interplay of inductive effect, solvation effect, and steric hindrance in determining the basic strength of alkylamines in aqueous solution. Propose an explanation for the observed order of basicity among methyl and ethyl substituted amines.
correct_answer: The basicity of alkylamines in aqueous solution results from a balance between several factors. The inductive (+I) effect of alkyl groups increases electron density on the nitrogen, making the amine more basic. However, when an amine is protonated, the resulting ammonium ion’s stability also depends on solvation. Primary ammonium ions have more available hydrogen atoms to participate in hydrogen bonding with water, leading to better solvation and stabilization, whereas steric hindrance in secondary and tertiary ammonium ions reduces the extent of solvation. This means that although in the gas phase, basicity might increase with more alkyl substitution (tertiary > secondary > primary), in aqueous solution the enhanced solvation of the primary ammonium ion outweighs the inductive donation provided by additional alkyl groups. Thus, for methyl-substituted and ethyl-substituted amines, the order in water tends to be: (CH₃)₂NH > CH₃NH₂ > (CH₃)₃N > NH₃ and (C₂H₅)₂NH > (C₂H₅)₃N > C₂H₅NH₂ > NH₃, reflecting the subtle interplay of these factors.
explanation: This explanation considers both electronic and physical interactions. While the electron-donating inductive effect increases basicity, the extent of solvation by water is crucial in aqueous environments. Steric hindrance reduces solvation efficiency, causing a reversal in the basicity trend compared to the gas phase.

question_text: True or False: Benzenesulphonyl chloride reacts with tertiary amines to form sulphonamides.
correct_answer: False
explanation: Tertiary amines do not react with benzenesulphonyl chloride to form sulphonamides because they lack an N–H proton, which is necessary for the reaction to occur.

question_text: True or False: Amines act as Lewis bases because of the availability of an unshared pair of electrons on the nitrogen atom.
correct_answer: True
explanation: Amines are Lewis bases since the unshared pair on the nitrogen atom can be donated to accept a proton or coordinate with electrophiles.

question_text: True or False: In aqueous solution, tertiary aliphatic amines are generally stronger bases than primary aliphatic amines due to the strong +I effect of alkyl groups.
correct_answer: False
explanation: While the inductive effect of alkyl groups increases basicity in the gas phase, in aqueous solution, the decreased solvation of the bulkier tertiary ammonium ions results in primary amines being stronger bases.

question_text: Calculate the pKb for an amine if its base dissociation constant (Kb) is 1.0 × 10⁻⁴.
correct_answer: pKb = 4
explanation: The pKb is defined as -log Kb. Therefore, pKb = -log(1.0 × 10⁻⁴) = 4.

question_text: A solution of C₂H₅NH₂ is prepared by reacting 0.1 mol of C₂H₅NH₂ with 0.1 mol HCl to form its ammonium salt in a final volume of 1 L. If the pKb of C₂H₅NH₂ is 3.29, calculate the pH of the resulting solution.
correct_answer: The pH of the solution is approximately 5.86
explanation: First, for the base C₂H₅NH₂ with pKb = 3.29, the corresponding conjugate acid has pKa = 14 - 3.29 = 10.71 (using pKa + pKb = 14). For a 0.1 M solution of the weak acid, the pH can be estimated using the formula for weak acid hydrolysis: pH = 0.5 × (pKa - log C). Here, log(0.1) = -1, so pH = 0.5 × (10.71 + 1) = 0.5 × 11.71 ≈ 5.86.

question_text: Calculate the base dissociation constant (Kb) for methylamine if its pKb is 3.36.
explanation: The Kb is calculated using the relation Kb = 10^(-pKb). Therefore, for a pKb of 3.36, Kb = 10^(-3.36) ≈ 4.37 × 10⁻⁴.

question_text: In a carbylamine reaction, 0.05 mol of a primary amine reacts with an equimolar amount of CHCl₃ in the presence of excess ethanolic KOH, with an 80% theoretical yield of the isocyanide product. Given that the molar mass of the isocyanide is 81 g/mol, calculate the mass of isocyanide produced.
correct_answer: Approximately 3.24 g of isocyanide is produced.
explanation: First, calculate the moles of isocyanide formed: 0.05 mol × 80% = 0.04 mol. Then, mass = moles × molar mass = 0.04 mol × 81 g/mol = 3.24 g.

question_text: In the acylation reaction of C₂H₅NH₂ with CH₃COCl (C₂H₅NH₂ + CH₃COCl → C₂H₅NHCOCH₃ + HCl), if 20.0 mL of a 0.5 M C₂H₅NH₂ solution is used and CH₃COCl is in excess, calculate the theoretical yield of N-ethylethanamide (molar mass = 89 g/mol).
correct_answer: The theoretical yield is 0.89 g of N-ethylethanamide.
explanation: First, determine the moles of C₂H₅NH₂: 20.0 mL (0.020 L) × 0.5 M = 0.01 mol. Because the reaction is 1:1, 0.01 mol of N-ethylethanamide will be formed. Then, mass = moles × molar mass = 0.01 mol × 89 g/mol = 0.89 g.

question_text: Which of the following structures represents a secondary amine?
correct_answer: R-NHR'
explanation: A secondary amine is formed when two hydrogen atoms of ammonia are replaced by alkyl or aryl groups, yielding the structure R-NHR'.

question_text: A tertiary amine is formed by the replacement of how many hydrogen atoms in ammonia?
correct_answer: Three hydrogen atoms
explanation: Tertiary amines are produced when all three hydrogen atoms of ammonia are replaced by alkyl or aryl groups.

question_text: Which statement best explains the difference between 'simple' and 'mixed' amines?
options: Simple amines have one type of substituent while mixed amines have multiple types.
Simple amines always contain aryl groups, whereas mixed amines contain alkyl groups.
Simple amines are primary by nature and mixed amines are secondary.
There is no difference; both terms refer to the same concept.
correct_answer: Simple amines have one type of substituent while mixed amines have multiple types.
explanation: Simple amines are those in which all the alkyl or aryl groups are identical, while mixed amines have different substituents.

question_text: When one hydrogen atom of ammonia is replaced by an alkyl or aryl group, the compound formed is classified as which type of amine?
correct_answer: Primary amine
explanation: Replacing one hydrogen atom in ammonia with an alkyl or aryl group results in the formation of a primary amine (RNH₂ or ArNH₂).

question_text: Identify the correct structure for a tertiary amine from the following options.
explanation: A tertiary amine is formed when three hydrogen atoms of ammonia are replaced by alkyl or aryl groups, represented by the structure R-N(R')-R''.

question_text: Explain how a primary amine is formed starting from the ammonia molecule.
correct_answer: A primary amine is formed by replacing one hydrogen atom of ammonia with an alkyl or aryl group, resulting in the structure RNH₂ or ArNH₂.
explanation: In the formation of a primary amine, one H in NH₃ is substituted by an R or Ar group. This process changes the molecule from ammonia to a primary amine.

question_text: Classify the structure R-NHR'. What type of amine does it represent and why?
correct_answer: R-NHR' represents a secondary amine because two of the hydrogen atoms in ammonia have been replaced by alkyl or aryl groups.
explanation: The structure R-NHR' indicates that two substitutions have occurred on the ammonia molecule, leaving one hydrogen attached to the nitrogen. This defines it as a secondary amine.

question_text: Define the terms 'simple' and 'mixed' as used in the classification of amines.
correct_answer: Simple amines have identical alkyl or aryl groups attached to the nitrogen, while mixed amines have different substituents attached.
explanation: The textbook defines simple amines as those where all the alkyl or aryl groups are the same, whereas mixed amines contain a variety of substituents.

question_text: Why are aryl groups considered in the classification of amines along with alkyl groups?
correct_answer: Aryl groups are considered because they can replace hydrogen atoms in ammonia similarly to alkyl groups, forming arylamines that share similar classification as primary, secondary, or tertiary amines.
explanation: The classification of amines is based on the number of substitutions regardless of whether the substituent is an alkyl or an aryl group. Both types are included because their substitution leads to analogous molecular structures.

question_text: Compare and contrast primary, secondary, and tertiary amines in terms of their formation and molecular structure.
correct_answer: Primary amines are formed when one hydrogen atom of ammonia is replaced by an R or Ar group (RNH₂), secondary amines by replacing two hydrogens (R-NHR'), and tertiary amines by replacing all three hydrogens (R-N(R')-R'').
explanation: Primary amines have one substituent attached to nitrogen, secondary have two, and tertiary have three. This substitution affects not only their molecular structures but also properties like basicity and steric hindrance. Primary amines may be more reactive due to less steric hindrance, while tertiary amines, having three substituents, are typically more sterically hindered.

question_text: Discuss how the substitution pattern (number and type of substituents) in an amine influences its basicity and reactivity.
correct_answer: Substitution pattern affects basicity by altering electron density around the nitrogen atom. Alkyl groups, being electron-donating, increase basicity, but increased substitution can also introduce steric hindrance which may lower the accessibility of the nitrogen lone pair for bonding.
explanation: While electron-donating groups increase the electron density on nitrogen, making the amine more basic, more bulky substituents can hinder the approach of electrophiles. Therefore, secondary and tertiary amines show a balance between increased electron donation and steric hindrance, influencing their reactivity and overall basicity.

question_text: Explain the effect of replacing hydrogen atoms in ammonia with alkyl or aryl groups on both the steric effects and electron donating effects in the resulting amine.
correct_answer: Replacing hydrogen atoms with alkyl or aryl groups introduces electron-donating effects which typically enhance the basicity of the amine. However, as substitution increases, the steric hindrance around the nitrogen also increases, which can impede interactions with reagents and slightly reduce reactivity in certain contexts.
explanation: The substitution increases the electron density through inductive effects, improving the ability of the nitrogen to donate its lone pair. Simultaneously, larger or additional substituents can create steric hindrance that affects the overall reactivity and the accessibility of the nitrogen, thereby influencing the chemical properties.

question_text: True or False: A primary amine is formed by replacing one hydrogen atom in ammonia with an alkyl or aryl group.
correct_answer: True
explanation: A primary amine is exactly defined as the product of replacing one hydrogen atom in ammonia, resulting in structures like RNH₂ or ArNH₂.

question_text: True or False: Replacement of one hydrogen atom in ammonia immediately produces a secondary amine.
correct_answer: False
explanation: Replacing one hydrogen atom in ammonia yields a primary amine, not a secondary amine. A secondary amine requires the replacement of two hydrogen atoms.

question_text: True or False: Tertiary amines always consist of three different groups attached to the nitrogen atom.
correct_answer: False
explanation: Tertiary amines are characterized by three substituents attached to nitrogen but these groups can be the same or different. When all substituents are identical, the amine is referred to as simple, and when they are different, it is termed mixed.

question_text: Numerical: If 0.2 mole of ammonia is used to synthesize a tertiary amine, how many moles of alkyl or aryl groups are required for complete substitution? Show your calculation.
correct_answer: 0.6 mole of alkyl or aryl groups
explanation: A tertiary amine is formed by substituting all three hydrogen atoms in ammonia. Therefore, for 0.2 mole of ammonia, the number of substituent groups required is 3 x 0.2 = 0.6 mole.

question_text: Numerical: A simple tertiary amine is formed when each hydrogen in ammonia is replaced by an R group. Given that the molar mass of NH3 is 17.03 g/mol, the atomic mass of nitrogen is 14.01 g/mol, and each R group has a mass of 15.00 g/mol, calculate the molar mass of the resulting tertiary amine R3N. Then, find the total mass when 0.1 mole of R3N is produced.
correct_answer: The molar mass is 59.01 g/mol and the mass for 0.1 mole is 5.901 g.
explanation: A tertiary amine R3N consists of one nitrogen and three R groups. Molar mass = 14.01 + (3 x 15.00) = 14.01 + 45.00 = 59.01 g/mol. For 0.1 mole, mass = 0.1 x 59.01 g = 5.901 g.

question_text: Numerical: Ammonia (NH3) has a molar mass of 17.03 g/mol. When one hydrogen atom (1.008 g/mol) is replaced in ammonia by an ethyl group (C2H5) of mass 29.06 g/mol, compute the molar mass of the resulting primary amine and determine the percentage increase in molar mass compared to ammonia.
correct_answer: The molar mass of the primary amine is approximately 45.09 g/mol, representing an increase of about 164.2%.
explanation: The primary amine has the structure RNH2. Molar mass = mass of ethyl group (29.06) + mass of nitrogen (14.01) + mass of 2 hydrogens (2 x 1.008 = 2.016) = 29.06 + 14.01 + 2.016 = 45.086 g/mol (approximately 45.09 g/mol). The percentage increase is ((45.09 - 17.03)/17.03) x 100 ≈ 164.2%.

question_text: Numerical: A mixed secondary amine, R-NH-R', is prepared using a methyl group (CH3, approximately 15.04 g/mol) and an ethyl group (C2H5, approximately 29.06 g/mol). Given that the atomic mass of nitrogen is 14.01 g/mol and hydrogen is 1.008 g/mol, calculate the approximate molar mass of the mixed secondary amine CH3NHCH2CH3.

question_text: Analyze the reaction mechanism for the diazotisation of aniline. In your answer, include the role of nitrous acid and the overall stoichiometry of the reaction.

Nitrous acid then protonates to form the nitrosonium ion, which is an electrophile. The nitrosonium ion reacts with the electron-rich amino group of aniline to form an intermediate, which then loses a proton to yield the diazonium ion. The overall stoichiometry is: C₆H₅NH₂ + NaNO₂ + 2HCl → C₆H₅N₂⁺Cl⁻ + NaCl + 2H₂O.

Aniline, with its nucleophilic amino group, attacks NO⁺ to form an N-nitrosoamine intermediate, which rearranges and loses water to form the diazonium ion. The stoichiometry reflects the necessary balancing of all reactants and by-products.

question_text: Why is the bond angle in amines less than the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5°?

question_text: Which of the following best describes the molecular geometry of simple amines?

question_text: Define sp3 hybridization in the context of amines.

question_text: How does the presence of a lone pair of electrons affect the C–N–E bond angle in amines?
correct_answer: The lone pair exerts greater repulsion than bonding pairs, reducing the bond angle below the ideal tetrahedral angle (109.5°), as evidenced by the 108° angle in trimethylamine.
explanation: Because lone pairs are more electron dense, they repel the bonding electrons more strongly, thus compressing the bond angles between the bonded atoms.

question_text: Explain how the three sp3 hybridized orbitals of nitrogen form bonds with surrounding atoms in amines.
correct_answer: Each of the three sp3 hybridized orbitals overlaps with the orbitals of hydrogen or carbon atoms to form sigma bonds; the remaining orbital holds the lone pair.
explanation: This bonding pattern explains the pyramidal geometry of amines and accounts for the chemical behavior seen due to the lone pair.

question_text: Discuss the impact of the unshared electron pair on the geometry and reactivity of amines.
correct_answer: The unshared electron pair on nitrogen in amines significantly influences both geometry and reactivity. Geometrically, the lone pair occupies more space than bonding pairs, leading to a reduction of the bond angle from the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5° to around 108°. This distortion results in a pyramidal molecular shape. In terms of reactivity, the lone pair is available for donation, making amines nucleophilic and basic. This property is important in many chemical reactions, such as nucleophilic substitutions and acid-base reactions.
explanation: The presence of a lone pair not only alters the spatial arrangement of atoms around nitrogen but also enhances the chemical reactivity due to increased electron density. This dual effect is fundamental in understanding amine behavior in organic chemistry.

question_text: Explain in detail the sp3 hybridization process of nitrogen in amines and compare it to the electronic configuration of ammonia.
correct_answer: In both amines and ammonia, the nitrogen atom has five valence electrons. Through sp3 hybridization, one s and three p orbitals mix to form four equivalent orbitals. In ammonia, three of these orbitals form sigma bonds with hydrogen atoms and one holds the lone pair, resulting in a trigonal pyramidal shape. Similarly, in amines, three sp3 orbitals form bonds with either hydrogen or carbon atoms while the remaining orbital contains the lone pair, leading to a similar pyramidal geometry, albeit with different substituents.
explanation: The process of sp3 hybridization explains the molecular geometry and bonding in both ammonia and amines. The main difference lies in the nature of the substituents attached to nitrogen, which can influence the bond angles slightly due to varied steric and electronic effects.

question_text: Discuss how diazonium salts can be utilized to introduce substituents that are otherwise inaccessible through direct substitution in benzene. Provide examples and reaction conditions where applicable.

question_text: Compare and contrast the common and IUPAC naming systems for amines. Discuss at least two differences in their approaches with suitable examples.
correct_answer: The common system names primary amines as a single word like 'methylamine' whereas the IUPAC system names them as alkanamines such as 'methanamine'. In addition, for secondary and tertiary amines, the common system uses simple prefixes like 'ethylmethylamine' while the IUPAC system employs the use of 'N' locants, as in 'N-methylethanamine'.
explanation: The common system often uses a straightforward approach by combining the alkyl group name and 'amine' directly, which can sometimes be less descriptive about the actual position of the functional group. The IUPAC system, however, clearly states the position of the -NH₂ group by converting the alkane name (replacing 'e' with 'amine') and using numerical locants. This detailed approach is especially useful for molecules with multiple functional groups, like ethane-1,2-diamine where the positions of each amino group are specified.

question_text: Discuss the nomenclature rules for secondary amines in both the common system and IUPAC system, and explain why the locant 'N' is used with supporting examples.

This use of 'N' clearly distinguishes substituents on nitrogen from substituents on the carbon chain, which is particularly important for molecules with complex structures or multiple functional groups.
explanation: The locant 'N' in IUPAC nomenclature serves to eliminate ambiguity about the point of attachment of substituents. This explicit designation contrasts with the common system, where such detail is often inferred or omitted, potentially leading to confusion in more complex molecules.

question_text: Write the overall reaction for the conversion of chloroethane (C₂H₅Cl) into ethylamine (C₂H₅NH₂) using ammonolysis. Include the formation of minor products.

question_text: What is the role of using a large excess of ammonia in the ammonolysis reaction of alkyl halides?
correct_answer: A large excess of ammonia minimizes further alkylation of the primary amine, thereby favoring its formation over secondary, tertiary, or quaternary products.
explanation: When ammonia is in excess, it competes more effectively with the primary amine for reacting with alkyl halide, thereby reducing the formation of more substituted amines and favoring the primary amine product.

question_text: Discuss the mechanism of Gabriel phthalimide synthesis for the preparation of primary amines. Include the reaction steps and explain why it is not suitable for aromatic amines.
correct_answer: The Gabriel synthesis involves converting phthalimide to its potassium salt with ethanolic KOH, followed by reaction with an alkyl halide to form N-alkylphthalimide. This intermediate is then subjected to alkaline hydrolysis to yield the primary amine and sodium phthalate. Aromatic amines cannot be obtained because aryl halides do not undergo nucleophilic substitution with the phthalimide anion due to the stability and lack of reactivity of the aryl carbon-halogen bond.
explanation: The process starts with deprotonation of phthalimide to form its salt, which attacks the alkyl halide via an S_N2 mechanism forming N-alkylphthalimide. Subsequent base hydrolysis removes the phthalimide group, yielding the primary amine. The inability of aryl halides to participate in the S_N2 mechanism due to partial double bond character in the C–X bond explains why aromatic amines are not produced.

question_text: Explain the sequence of reactions in ammonolysis that lead to the formation of quaternary ammonium salts. How can reaction conditions be adjusted to maximize the yield of primary amines?
correct_answer: Ammonolysis begins with the nucleophilic substitution of an alkyl halide by ammonia to form a primary ammonium salt which, under the reaction conditions, can lose a proton to form a free primary amine. This free amine can further react with another alkyl halide to form a secondary amine, and continued alkylations eventually form tertiary amine and finally a quaternary ammonium salt. To maximize primary amine yield, a large excess of ammonia is used which minimizes further alkylation of the formed primary amine.
explanation: The sequential S_N2 reactions involve initial formation of a substituted ammonium salt that can deprotonate. Each successive alkylation results in a higher substituted amine. By employing a large excess of ammonia, the probability of the free primary amine encountering additional alkyl halide is reduced, hence favoring the primary amine product.
